content: Hi! I am Peimin, welcome to my blog! I will continue to update, please keep following me!
summary: Hi! I am Peimin, welcome to my blog! I will continue to update, please keep following me!
title: Peimin Lin

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]]name = "Courses"url = "courses/"weight = 50 Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]]name = "Docs"url = "docs/"weight = 50 Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
This project is intended to explore covid-19 cases of confirmed, death and recovered in 10 main countries around the world. The code is available on Github. The project began as an attempt to compare difference type of cases in 10 countries through difference date range. The second one is use map to have a better visualisation in a particular day in difference type cases. The radius represented the number of the cases, the bigger, there were more cases. For the last one is the DT table that can have a better understanding of each countries difference type and exact day cases.
DataThe data that was used for all visualizations are provided by the Johns Hopkins University Center for Systems Science and Engineering (JHU CSSE) who pulled their data on a public Github page and Rami Krispin and other 4 contributor provided a tidy format of the data that named coronavirus. As the dataset were too large that I only choose 10 main countries that have severe outbreak and select the data from 22nd Jan to 31st Jul 2020. The data set have 7 variables contained data, province in some countries, longitude, latitude and cases number of three different types.
The Open DashboardThe overview section of the dashboard is a plot visualizing comparison of interesting countries through date range and types of the COVID-19 pandemic progression. There are checkboxes for choosing interesting countries, date range selection for the y-axis can be switched to correspond date interval and select interesting types about confirmed, death and recovered cases. At the bottom of the plot, I set the event data that when you click the plot that will show the exact number of the cases in the box.From this dashboard, I used leaflet to create another dashboard shows better visualizations of the COVID-19 pandemics through worldwide map. Different from the open section, this map only show one day that you would be interested in through a date selection and select the cases type of the cases. At there are some countries increased sharply in some specific day that I set the shadow radius as the logarithm squared of cases number.The table section contains the DT table that list all countries and three of cases, you can select your interested countries to view all the number of three types or one particularly type through select function at the bottom. Meanwhile, DT table also allows you to search key word through the search engine and arrange the number order. The dashboard is rounded off with the “About” section which describes the motivation, data sources and the tool I use for my first shinyapp.ConsiderationsFor the data set I used was only a date range and I would like to have a keep updating data set that have better comparison in different ranges. There are various of uncertainty in the data set, some cases might not record, or some testing procedure did not compete that will have a different result for the cases number recorded. Because the shinyapp select input shortage, I only choose 10 main countries for comparison, I would like to add more countries and more variable in the plot. Also, I would like to try adding event data in map section.
ImprovementAs I am not the expert of the Shinyapp that I cannot fully design the plot that I wanted, if I have a better understanding the event data that I would like to update the event box x-axis and y-axis variable names. Moreover, I did not adjust the right position of the select input in each section. Thus, for a better visualisation for each dashboard, I only set the select boxes in the non-conflict with the main section. I would like to have more discussion about my idea in the ‘About’ section.
ContributeAfter choosing the data, there are three section came up my mind that I should create a map which was the best way to overview the pandemic situation between different countries, a plot can show the trend and the table show the clear number of the cases. When I done the basic shinyapp, I began to add some fancy layer in for my shinyapp that create a dashboard and boxes. Found the relative icon of the section in Font Awesome to put in my manu panel. Setting my favourite colour as the background colour through HTML function in ui.
Sourceshttps://rstudio.github.io/leaflet/https://fontawesome.com/icons?from=ioDataJohns Hopkins CSSE COVID-19 Cases
R Packages coronavirus
summary: This project is intended to explore covid-19 cases of confirmed, death and recovered in 10 main countries around the world. The code is available on Github. The project began as an attempt to compare difference type of cases in 10 countries through difference date range.
title: Covid-19 Shinyapp Exploration

content:
The blog is a further research about COVID-19 in Belgium in economic aspect. According to Johns Hopkins University Center for System Science and Engineering invention provided latest version of the data, in the first 180 days Belgium reported death number took a small place in the European Union, however, Belgium took the highest death rate in the world which we found the result in the last blog. Figure 1 shows reported deaths number in 8 particular European countries in the first 180 days since the epidemic spread out. The graph shows the same trend were increased rapidly in the first 50 days.
Figure 1: Reported deaths number in European Union.Thanks for lockdown policy in many countries that made the outbreak under control, in Figure 2 that the latest update in 16th Sep 2020, reported deaths number in European mostly were under 100 cases. In Belgium, it seems that outbreak is under control that keep the number under 10 cases. For further research can have a look at tidycovid19
Figure 2: Covid19:Reported deaths(new cases per day)Impact of Gross Domestic Product in BelgiumAs it surveys an economy ravaged by the disease, Figure 3 which dataset was downloaded from Real Gross Domestic Product for Belgium shows that Belgium real gross domestic product (GDP) from first quarter of 2005 to first quarter of 2020. There are two apparent fluctuations that one was from 2008 to 2009 which meet economic crisis, another one was from late 2019 to recent which under COVID-19 outbreak. The horizon line can clearly clarify that first quarter of 2020, GDP for Belgium fell to same level of 2019 which just went through an economic crisis.
Figure 3: Real GDP in BelgiumComparison GDP between Euro Aera and BelgiumFor a better understanding what impact that virus bring to, I found 19 countries in European aera of their total GDP resources from Gross Domestic Product for Euro area (19 countries). Figure 4 compared to total GDP of 19 countries in European area, Belgium’s GDP have a same moving trend as European countries. However, in the last two quarter that Belgium has wider variations than normal.
Figure 4: GDP comparison between Belgium and European Union(19 countries)Impact of Unemployment Rate in BelgiumMeanwhile, Belgium limps back to work after the outbreak, citizens job prospects are truly bleak. It was a period that the workforce as prospective employers mull lay-offs of hiring freezes. For a middle class used to relentlessly strong economic growth, the stock will be great. Figure 5 illustrated unemployment rate from first quarter of 2015 to first quarter of 2020, it seems that there was a tendency to decrease unemployment rate since 2015 before epidemic happened. The latest data showed that unemployment rate in Belgium has obvious rose in first quarter in 2020.
Figure 5: Unemployment Rate in BelgiumComparison Unemployment Rate between Euro Area and BelgiumComparing unemployment rate around European area, Belgium unemployment rate was higher than average from the past five year but all with a bright future that unemployment rate fell year by year even Figure 6 shown the gap between Belgium and average European area was increasingly getting bigger. With an unexpected epidemic that every thing seems changed that both have a same turning point since 2020, the tide of unemployment was coming fast and furious and we don’t know how long will this cold wave last. If you have interest for impact in economy, I would like to recommend you to visit Alfred which recorded variance of economy historial data.
Figure 6: Comparison of Unemployment Rate between Belgium and Euro areaThere is no doubt that virus has hit every country hard and it is a big question that we don’t know how bad will COVID-19 be for the economy around the world. There are so many bad news in 2020 and hopefully we can get COVID-19 vaccine soon and pull through together.
ReferenceKun Ren and Kenton Russell (2019). formattable: Create ‘Formattable’ Data Structures.https://renkun.me/formattable,
Allaire, J, Y Xie, J McPherson, J Luraschi, K Ushey, A Atkins, H Wickham, J Cheng, W Chang, and R Iannone (2020). rmarkdown: Dynamic Documents for R. R package version 2.1. https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
Grolemund, G and H Wickham (2011). Dates and Times Made Easy with lubridate. Journal of Statistical Software 40(3), 1–25.
Wickham, H, M Averick, J Bryan, W Chang, LD McGowan, R François, G Grolemund, A Hayes, L Henry, J Hester, M Kuhn, TL Pedersen, E Miller, SM Bache, K Müller, J Ooms, D Robinson, DP Seidel, V Spinu, K Takahashi, D Vaughan, C Wilke, K Woo, and H Yutani (2019). Welcome to the tidyverse. Journal of Open Source Software 4(43), 1686.
Joachim Gassen (2020). tidycovid19: Download, Tidy and Visualize Covid-19 Related Data. R package version 0.0.0.9000.
Steve Miller (2020). stevemisc: Miscellaneous Functions/Data That Only Steve Finds Useful. R package version 0.1.17.
Xie, Y (2020a). bookdown: Authoring Books and Technical Documents with R Markdown. R package version 0.18. https://github.com/rstudio/bookdown
Onno Kleen (2020). alfred: Downloading Time Series from ALFRED Database for Various Vintages. R package version 0.1.8. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=alfred
summary: The blog is a further research about COVID-19 in Belgium in economic aspect. According to Johns Hopkins University Center for System Science and Engineering invention provided latest version of the data, in the first 180 days Belgium reported death number took a small place in the European Union, however, Belgium took the highest death rate in the world which we found the result in the last blog.
title: The impact of Covid-19 in Belgium

content:
The blog is a research about coronavirus(COVID-19) in Belgium from March 2020 to August 2020 and used the data source from Kaggle and used the dataset from package coronavirus.
You can visualise the number of COVID-19 cased confirmed in Belgium from March to August 2020 in Figure 1. It shows that April was the most seriousness month that have the largest infected population. Since then, people started pay attention and took anti-epidemic action and the confirmed cases got a good result. However, there are still have high number of confirmed cases.
+-{"x":{"items":[{"content":"3761","start":"2020-03"},{"content":"5343","start":"2020-04"},{"content":"3620","start":"2020-05"},{"content":"2086","start":"2020-06"},{"content":"2949","start":"2020-07"},{"content":"3694","start":"2020-08"}],"groups":null,"showZoom":false,"zoomFactor":0.5,"fit":true,"options":[],"height":"150px","api":[]},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}Figure 1: Cases confrimed in Belgium since March 2020For further research, it found that the elder got higher infected rate, the table show below listed confirmed cases in difference provinces and regions and difference age group. It shows that the largest number were from 80-89 age group in every region in April.
VariablesMONTHREGIONPROVINCEAGEGROUPNUMBER14FlandersWestVlaanderen80-896324BrusselsBrussels80-896234FlandersAntwerpen80-896244FlandersWestVlaanderen50-596254FlandersOostVlaanderen50-596064FlandersOostVlaanderen80-896074WalloniaHainaut70-796084WalloniaHainaut80-896094BrusselsBrussels70-7959104FlandersAntwerpen50-5959We found that not only did the elder would easier infected, but also got a higher death rate. Figure 2 shown below that number of mortality in three regions in Belgium, all the age group people in the lists and especially in the elder group. Brussels is the least number of mortality among the data set.
Figure 2: Mortaity numbers from March to August in three reigionsCompare with United State and China which are the country got serious epidemic, we calculate the death rate and recovery rate. The interactive table shows below that Belgium got the second highest death rate in April. During this research, I found an article online said that Belgium got the highest death rate around the world. What made Belgium rank the first place? If you interested about it, you can spend few minutes to have a look Is Belgium the world’s deadliest COVID-19 country or just the most honest?
Belgium is a beautiful country, it is famous for its chocolate and it has plenty of historical treasures. Hope the epidemic will end soon and I will have the opportunity to travel.

summary: The blog is a research about coronavirus(COVID-19) in Belgium from March 2020 to August 2020 and used the data source from Kaggle and used the dataset from package coronavirus.
title: Coronavirus in Belgium

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry"if porridge == "blueberry":print("Eating...")  Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}} Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}}- Only the speaker can read these notes- Press `S` key to view{{% /speaker_note %}} Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}}{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}{{< slide class="my-style" >}}  Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1,.reveal section h2,.reveal section h3 {color: navy;}  Questions? Ask
Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides
